title: Drink driver who killed woman in tent as she slept is jailed for eight years
text:
Jake Waterhouse has been jailed for causing the death of Anna Evans after he drove into her tent on the Rhyd y Galen campsite near Bethel, Caernarfon (Picture: PA)

A drunk-driver who crashed into a campsite fatally injuring a mum sleeping in her tent has been jailed.

Jake Waterhouse, 27, careered off the road and smashed into a quiet North Wales campsite at 2am.

He hit the tent of Anna Roselyn Evans, 46, who died in hospital nine days after the incident in August this year.

Three other campers were injured when Waterhouse lost control of his friend’s Subaru Impreza.

He admitted causing death by dangerous driving and has today been jailed for more than eight years at Mold Crown Court.

Anna Evans worked for the Royal Commission on the Ancient and Historical Monuments of Wales (RCAHMW) (Picture: PA)

Prosecutor Sion ap Mihangel told the court that Waterhouse and friend Philip Eves had been drinking Jack Daniels and lager at the Rhyd y Galen campsite near Caernarfon, north Wales.

The father-of-two, who only had a provisional licence, then took Mr Eves’ car for a drunken ride in the early hours of Monday August 19.

He first collided with the tent of Neil Cook and partner Megan Lazenby, who suffered minor injuries.

Waterhouse, of Partington, Manchester, then careered into the tent where Mrs Evans was asleep alongside her husband Huw.

Mr ap Mihangel said Mr Evans was woken by ‘an almighty bang’ and had to be cut free from the tent.

He could not find his wife until he eventually saw her legs sticking out from underneath the car.

Jake Waterhouse has been jailed for eight years and four months for causing the death by dangerous driving of Anna Evans (Picture: PA)

Mrs Evans, an artist of Aberystwyth, West Wales, was rushed to Ysbyty Gwynedd but later transferred to a major trauma unit in Stoke, where she died on August 27.

In a statement, her husband said her death had had an emotional impact on all of the family, including her children Lowri, 25, and Richard, 24.

He said: ‘Anna was the love of my life and it will be so difficult to move on, especially with the manner in which she was taken away from us.’

At the time of her death, her son said: ‘She was my mother, my best friend, my rock and I’m going to miss her so so much.

‘She inspired me to do music, art and to always “do the next interesting thing”. I know I’ll do you proud.’

Waterhouse initially fled the scene but returned after a phone call to his mother who told him to do the ‘right thing.’

He tested positive for alcohol but later gave insufficient breath tests and refused to give more specimens at the police station.

Jake Waterhouse careered off the road and smashed into the quiet campsite at 2am (Picture: Wales News Service)

The court heard Waterhouse had a number of previous convictions, including for violence, criminal damage, driving without insurance and driving not in accordance with a licence.

Matthew Curtis, defending, said his client was genuinely remorseful and had attempted to write a letter to the family of Mrs Evans.

He said: ‘He has been unable to get beyond a paragraph and he knows the words would never be the right words or enough.’

Jailing Waterhouse for eight years and four months, Judge Rhys Rowlands said it was an act ‘of the most appalling irresponsibility’.

He said: ‘I could so easily have been sentencing you for causing the death of not just one person but, in reality, four that night.’

Mentioning Mrs Evans’ wishes that her organs be donated, the judge added: ‘If ever there was a woman, mother, who contributed to her family and her community in life, but also in death, it seems a huge tragedy.’

Waterhouse, who was in tears at times in the dock, had already admitted driving otherwise than in accordance with a licence, driving with no insurance and failing to provide a breath specimen for analysis when he appeared at Llandudno Magistrates’ Court in August.

He was also disqualified from driving for 12 years and two months.
